title: 1585-C
statement: C. Minimize Distancetime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputA total of $$$n$$$ depots are located on a number line. Depot $$$i$$$ lies at the point $$$x_i$$$ for $$$1 \\le i \\le n$$$.You are a salesman with $$$n$$$ bags of goods, attempting to deliver one bag to each of the $$$n$$$ depots. You and the $$$n$$$ bags are initially at the origin $$$0$$$. You can carry up to $$$k$$$ bags at a time. You must collect the required number of goods from the origin, deliver them to the respective depots, and then return to the origin to collect your next batch of goods.Calculate the minimum distance you need to cover to deliver all the bags of goods to the depots. You donothave to return to the origin after you have delivered all the bags.InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10\\,500$$$). Description of the test cases follows.The first line of each test case contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le k \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$).The second line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$x_1, x_2, \\ldots, x_n$$$ ($$$-10^9 \\le x_i \\le 10^9$$$). It is possible that some depots share the same position.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, output a single integer denoting the minimum distance you need to cover to deliver all the bags of goods to the depots.ExampleInput4 5 1 1 2 3 4 5 9 3 -5 -10 -15 6 5 8 3 7 4 5 3 2 2 3 3 3 4 2 1000000000 1000000000 1000000000 1000000000Output25 41 7 3000000000NoteIn the first test case, you can carry only one bag at a time. Thus, the following is a solution sequence that gives a minimum travel distance: $$$0 \\to 2 \\to 0 \\to 4 \\to 0 \\to 3 \\to 0 \\to 1 \\to 0 \\to 5$$$, where each $$$0$$$ means you go the origin and grab one bag, and each positive integer means you deliver the bag to a depot at this coordinate, giving a total distance of $$$25$$$ units. It must be noted that there are other sequences that give the same distance.In the second test case, you can follow the following sequence, among multiple such sequences, to travel minimum distance: $$$0 \\to 6 \\to 8 \\to 7 \\to 0 \\to 5 \\to 4 \\to 3 \\to 0 \\to (-5) \\to (-10) \\to (-15)$$$, with distance $$$41$$$. It can be shown that $$$41$$$ is the optimal distance for this test case.

You have $n$ bags of goods and $n$ depots located at points $x_1, x_2, ..., x_n$ on a number line. You start at the origin (0). You can carry up to $k$ bags at a time. 

You need to:

1. Collect bags from the origin.
2. Deliver the bags to their respective depots.
3. Return to the origin to collect more bags.

Find the minimum total distance you need to travel to deliver all the bags. You don't need to return to the origin after delivering all the bags. 


**Input:**

* The first line contains the number of test cases, $t$.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains two integers, $n$ (number of depots) and $k$ (maximum bags you can carry).
    * The second line contains $n$ integers, $x_1, x_2, ..., x_n$ (the locations of the depots).

**Output:**

* For each test case, output a single integer representing the minimum distance traveled.
You have to deliver a set of items to a number of locations. You can carry a limited number of items at once. What is the shortest total distance you need to travel to deliver all the items?
